content.rendered:
So when you make a flow with screens, sometimes you have a situation where you want to let your user know where they are within that screen flow. Well my #SalesforceOhana, this can be done, quite easily I might add! I am here to tell you all about the Stage Variable and Stage Component within flows and how to use it so that you can have that fancy shmacy path at the top of your screens – and guess what, it’s a single little lightning component that gets to be re-used and for the flow side, everything is declarative!

Booya! Just what you wanted to hear, a point and click solution to add the path to your flows, now that is something with adding a few extra variables/elements for to get that much UI/UX for so little effort. Here is how you do it…

How To Create the Flow Stage Component

Sadly this one isn’t quite out of the box yet, however the Salesforce Developer Guide has everything you need for this little guy.

There are 2 different ways to make the Stage component, as a Screen Component or as a lightning:flow component. If you use a Screen Component, you will map a stage to the screen component attribute and the flow passes the stage’s label into the attribute. If you use a lightning:flow component, the onstatuschange attribute in the component will return the active stages and current stage names and labels.

c:flowStages_global

c:flowStages_global sits at the Lightning Page Level vs in the flow. The design file has the flowName attribute, making the component reusable and allows you to specify which flow to run in the properties panel.

c:flowStages_field

c:flowStages_field sits on the flow screens themselves. It has the stages assigned between each screen within the flow

Install Here

Install Here

How to Plan Your Flow

Before you start building your flow, you’ll want to plan your stages, both the list of what they are, their order, and if there is a split.

  1. List all the possible stages for your flow.
  2. Determine in which order the stages occur.
  3. Determine if you have any decisions and if stages are different depending on the decision
  4. Identify which stages are active by default. This step is optional, but when you identify the default active stages, you don’t have to populate $Flow.ActiveStages and $Flow.CurrentStage with an Assignment element at the beginning of your flow.
  5. Install the Stage Components to your org (you can find my install link here)

Variables & Elements to Know

The flow itself is pretty basic, but there are some pieces that are going to be new and that work differently. Let’s get to know those first.

  • First and foremost, there are your Stages that you planned.
  • There is also the Stage component
  • Screens for each stage
    • Fields on each screen
  • Assignment elements to assign the stages
  • A create or update records to save the data entered into Salesforce
  • $Flow.ActiveStages Global Variable used by Assignment, a collection of stages that are relevant to the current path of the flow.
    • For example, each item in a progress indicator corresponds to a stage in $Flow.ActiveStages.
  • $Flow.CurrentStage Global Variable used by assignment. The currently selected stage.
    • For example, the selected item in a progress indicator corresponds to $Flow.CurrentStage.

Assignments

Assigning variables for the stages is. a vital part of the Stage flow process. You will use the following variables for each stage to assign the current stage displayed.

$Flow.CurrentStage

Replace the stage selected in $Flow.CurrentStage.

$Flow.ActiveStages

Add or remove active stages in the $Flow.ActiveStages global variable.

Get Your Build On

Let’s get ready to BUILD!!! First things first, there are a few things in your org you need first:

  • You must use My Domain
  • Enable Lightning runtime for flows
  • Stage Components only work in Lightning Experience, so use Lightning

Create your Stages

  • In your sidebar go to Manager and click New Resource
  • Select a Resource Type of Stage
  • Enter your Stage Details, being clear enough to understand the use of the Stage
    • Don’t forget your Description!
    • The Order is important for Stage usage as well
  • Tip – Space your Stages with a Gap so you can easily add more in the future
    • Eg Stages 1, 5, 10, 15
    • Don’t forget to check default if you want them in the Path displayed when an interview starts.
  • Create your First Screen

Use c:flowStages_field

  • On the first stage screen add  {!$Flow.CurrentStage} to the Current Stage and {$Flow.ActiveStages} to the Stages field
  • Add the assignment before the next screen on the flow showing the next section of the path
  • Assign the variables {!$Flow.CurrentStage} and {!$Flow.ActiveStages} for the next screen
  • Assign the next stage in an Assignment Variable, by merely assigning the Stage Resource to the Current Stage.
  • Repeat with each stage, adding the component flowStages_field to the screen and assigning the next stage

Use c:flowStages_global

As an alternative to the c:flowStages_field component, you can use the c:flowStages_global instead.

  • Add the c:flowStages_global component to a Lightning page (internal or community)
  • Add your flow name to the properties and viola!

Results

Each component has a little different look based on the components used.

The OOTB Flow component with the Flow_FieldStageComponent:

The Flow_global Component on a Lightning Page:

The Flow_global component on a page using a flow with the Flow_FieldStage Component on the screens:

Summary

How can you benefit from the Stage Feature and Component? What use cases can you think of? For me, I have found it great for surveys, large flows, onboarding, ecommerce, almost anything! Would love to hear your use cases, please share below.

Learn More about Flow
Flow Basics
